title: How to Access Open Voice Training Data: The Introduction
Transcript
body:
00:00:00 --> 00:00:08

Welcome to the course Open and unbiased AI Training Data: How to access open Voice Training Data

 

00:00:08  --> 00:00:16

This course is designed for students, researchers, developers, and anyone interested in voice-enabled and speech recognition technologies.

 

00:00:16 --> 00:00:42

In this course, we will

Introduce you to Mozilla’s Common Voice platform and its various functions.

Explore the various considerations for building good voice datasets.

Demonstrate how to create multi-language voice datasets.

Show you how to use the voice datasets in your projects to create a speech-to-text model with Mozilla’s DeepSpeech Technology

 

00:00:42 --> 00:00:58

At the end of this course, you will be able to:

Demonstrate knowledge of Mozilla’s Common Voice platform and its functionalities.

Identify a good voice dataset.

Create a multi-language voice dataset.

Practically use the voice dataset to create a speech-to-text model in your own project.

title: Practical Example: Use of Open Voice Data in the Makerere AI Research Lab
Transcript
body:
00:00:00 --> 00:00:16

Voice recognition technology is revolutionizing Human-Machine Interaction. However, currently available voice assistant systems, like Alexa and Google Assistant are proprietary and are not trained for the African context. 

 

00:00:16 --> 00:00:23

To fill this gap, Common Voice is a Mozilla platform initiative to provide better and more accessible voice technology.

 

00:00:23 --> 00:00:45

Mozilla’s Common Voice Platform provides:

A repository of high-quality, free and publicly available voice datasets

A comprehensive platform for crowdsourcing “Speak and Listen” contributions to a voice dataset

A mechanism for language localization

DeepSpeech Speech-To-Text engine

 

00:00:45 --> 00:01:08

Creating a multi-language dataset has 4 main steps.

  1. Localization of the common voice website. 

  2. Creation of a pure public sentence collection in a local language

  3. Reviewing the sentence collection in the local language

  4. Crowdsourcing voice contributions.

 

00:01:08 --> 00:01:38

We now illustrate localisation feature of the Common voice platform. To contribute to the English dataset, the instructions are provided in English. When creating a dataset in another language, the common voice website can be translated into that language. For example, we see here the platform translated to Kinyarwanda.

 

00:01:38 --> 00:02:08

The quality of a voice dataset hinges on a good sentence collection. All sentences submitted must be under Public Domain (Creative Commons-0) license. For example, such sentences can be collected from the Internet or through partnerships with local organisations and individuals. It is crucial that the sentences are reviewed for spelling, grammar and speakability. Lastly the preference is on both natural and conversational sentences.

 

00:02:08 --> 00:02:25

A good voice dataset should take into consideration the following aspects:

Should be unbiased regarding age, race and gender

Should be inclusive and for example account for non-native speakers

Should cater for all accents and dialects

title: Multi-select
body: Which of the following qualify as valid sources for when creating a public domain sentence collection for the Common voice platform?

_items.text: Partner with local university Institute of languages

title: Transcript
body:
00:00:00 --> 00:00:43

At the Makerere Artificial Intelligence Lab, We are building speech recognition models to be able to mine topical discussions from radio recordings. These recordings are very important both to government and NGO’s for them to understand issues around for example crop and pest disease surveillance, also around Covid-19 mentions on radio recordings and even other aspects for example gender based violence. In order for us to be able to build good speech recognition models that can mine radio recordings we need a very good voice dataset.

title: Transcript
body:
00:00:00 --> 00:00:31

One can contribute to a voice data set by either speaking or by listening and validating other’s contribution on the platform. 

To contribute your voice to a dataset, navigate to the Speaking section of the platform. Once there a sentence will be displayed and when ready to speak press the microphone icon to start the recording. To validate a sentence, navigate to the Listening section of the platform and indicate whether the recording was accurate or not.

You will now have your first practical assignment on the common voice platform where you will be required to create an account and contribute by both speaking and listening.

title: How to Contribute to a Voice Dataset
Question 3
body: DeepSpeech engine is helpful when using Mozilla’s Common Voice datasets to;

_items.text: Provide speech recognition during translation of voice to text.
Helps in conversion of text sentences to voice.
Helps in sentence validation when building a voice dataset.

title: What can you do with a Mozilla voice dataset?
Transcript
body:
00:00:00 --> 00:00:29

Now that you know how to build a good voice dataset, you can use it to: 

Build speech recognition platforms to assist visually and physically impaired technology users.

Unlock the power of the internet for those with  limited  literacy - especially local African languages.

Build voice recognition systems for radio and television

Build voice technology platforms for indigenous African languages that could potentially become extinct.

 

00:00:29 --> 00:01:34

Deepspeech is an AI based implementation of a Speech-to-text system built by Mozilla. To create a speech-to-text model for a specific language, follow the steps:

Download the dataset from the Common Voice platform.

Set up the DeepSpeech Environment.

Convert the Common voice data into Deepspeech format. 

You need to generate three CSV separate files namely train.csv, dev.csv, and test.csv for training, validation, and testing respectively.

Train your Speech-to-text model. 

Finally, Test your model

title: Transcript
body:
00:00:00 --> 00:00:11
A number of alternative Open Voice Data repositories exist, such as

Appen

https://appen.com/datasets/english-to-swahili-audio-recording-and-transcription/

 

Open Speech and Language Resources 

https://openslr.org/

 

Lwazi Speech Corpus

https://sites.google.com/site/lwazispeechcorpus/

 

Ajala Studios

https://thespindle.org/project/speech-technologies-for-addressing-digital-access-in-africa/

title: Transcript
body:
00:00:00 --> 00:00:18

Congratulations on completing the course how to access open Voice Training Data, you now know Mozilla’s Common Voice platform and its functionalities, you can build a good voice data set and can create a multi-language voice data set that you can use in your voice recognition projects. Thank you.

title: Course Outline
body:
Module Description

This e-learning video presents the process of creating open voice training data using Mozilla's common voice platform. The video will introduce the functionality and possibilities of the platform to learners. The video will also explain the relevance and local usefulness of voice data in African contexts. This will be through an example of how to use the voice data by using Mozilla’s DeepSpeech speech-to-text system. This course will also highlight other open voice data repositories that are relevant for the development of AI applications in the African context.

Target Group

This course is for students, researchers, developers, startups, and people working on voice-enabled and speech recognition technologies.

Module Objectives

In this course, we will

  • Introduce the learner to Mozilla’s Common Voice platform and its various functions.

  • Explore the various considerations for building good voice data sets.

  • Demonstrate how to create multi-language voice data sets.

  • How to use the voice datasets in your projects to create a speech-to-text model with Mozilla’s DeepSpeech Technology

Learning Outcomes

On completion of this course, you should be able to:

  • Demonstrate knowledge of Mozilla’s Common Voice platform and its functionalities.

  • Identify a good voice dataset.

  • Create a multi-language voice dataset.

  • Practically use the voice dataset to create a speech-to-text model in your own project.

Module Content

  1. Topic One: Introduction to Voice Technology - This topic will provide an introduction to Voice recognition technology and discuss how it is revolutionizing the way we interact with machines. Introduce the Common Voice platform as a way to make voice recognition technologies better and more accessible for everyone.

  2. Topic Two: Importance of Mozilla's Common Voice platform - This topic will introduce the importance and relevance of the Common voice platform in building voice recognition applications and also discuss its functionalities.

  3. Topic Three: How to add a new language to Common Voice - This topic will discuss the localisation steps that one can take to add a new language to the Common voice platform. These steps include the translation of Common Voice website a specific language and the collection of copyright-free sentences which have to be verified and availed for people to read out aloud through the Common voice sentence collector.

  4. Topic Four: Considerations for building good voice data sets - This topic will discuss the consideration for building good voice data sets. Considerations around quality, bias, inclusiveness, accents, dialects, gender, non-native speakers, sentence quality will be discussed.

  5. Topic Five: Deepspeech Model - This topic will discuss steps that can be taken in order to build a DeepSpeech speech-to-text system in a local context. This will be provided through a walk through from the downloading of data from the Common Voice platform to training an end-to-end speech recognition system using Mozilla's DeepSpeech models.

  6. Topic Six: Potential uses of voice data in the African Context - This topic will discuss several potential uses of voice data in the African context.

  7. Topic Seven: Alternative Open Voice Data Repositories - This topic provides an overview of alternative open voice data repositories. The types of data and the possible uses of the data will also be emphasized.

Study Mode

The mode of delivery will be through the Video which will be delivered by a Voice Over narration.

Mode of Assessment

Assessment will be through quiz questions and practical Jupypter notebooks for reflective learning assessment activities.

Reference Materials and Additional Materials

  1. https://deepspeech.readthedocs.io/en/v0.8.0/?badge=latest# This is the official documentation for the DeepSpeech, an open-source Speech-to-Text engine.

  2. Train Your Own Speech Recognition Model in 5 Simple Steps https://medium.com/visionwizard/train-your-own-speech-recognition-model-in-5-simple-steps-512d5ac348a5

  3. Mozilla's DeepSpeech and Common Voice projects https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NtZipf0BxKg Showcases an end to end training pipeline of the DeepSpeech model.

  4. Mozilla Speech and Machine Learning. https://research.mozilla.org/machine-learning/

  5. Hannun, A., Case, C., Casper, J., Catanzaro, B., Diamos, G., Elsen, E., Prenger, R., Satheesh, S., Sengupta, S., Coates, A. and Ng, A.Y. Deep speech: Scaling up end-to-end speech recognition. arXiv preprint arXiv:1412.5567 (2014).

  6. Ardila, R., Branson, M., Davis, K., Henretty, M., Kohler, M., Meyer, J., Morais, R., Saunders, L., Tyers, F.M. and Weber, G. Common Voice: A Massively-Multilingual Speech Corpus. arXiv preprint arXiv:1912.06670 (2019).

  7. Python Deep Learning (2nd Edition) by I. Vasilev, D. Slater, G. Spacagna, P. Roelants, V. Zocca Chapter 7: Recurrent Neural Networks and Language Models - Speech recognition. The chapter gives a brief overview of the speech recognition pipeline and provides a high-level view of how we can use neural networks in each part of the pipeline.

  8. Hands-On Natural Language Processing with Python by R. Shanmugamani & Rajesh Arumugam Chapter 11: Speech Recognition Using DeepSpeech. This chapter focuses on using recurrent neural network (RNNs) models for speech recognition, giving a detailed example on how to do speech recognition for continuous speech using DeepSpeech.
